maml:description.maml:para: Get scheduled task information from a system
Get scheduled task information from a system
Uses Schedule.Service COM object, falls back to SchTasks.exe as needed. When we fall back to SchTasks, we add empty properties to match the COM object output.
One or more computers to run this against
Scheduled tasks folder to query. By default, "\"
If specified, recurse through folders below $folder.
Note: We also recurse if we use SchTasks.exe
If specified, path to export XML files
Details: Naming scheme is computername-taskname.xml Please note that the base filename is used when importing a scheduled task. Rename these as needed prior to importing!
If specified, exclude tasks matching this regex (we use -notmatch $exclude)
One or more computers to run this against
Scheduled tasks folder to query. By default, "\"
If specified, exclude tasks matching this regex (we use -notmatch $exclude)
If specified, pull scheduled tasks only with the schtasks.exe command, which works against older systems.
Notes: Export is not possible with this switch. Recurse is implied with this switch.
One or more computers to run this against
Scheduled tasks folder to query. By default, "\"
If specified, recurse through folders below $folder.
Note: We also recurse if we use SchTasks.exe
If specified, path to export XML files
Details: Naming scheme is computername-taskname.xml Please note that the base filename is used when importing a scheduled task. Rename these as needed prior to importing!
If specified, exclude tasks matching this regex (we use -notmatch $exclude)
If specified, pull scheduled tasks only with the schtasks.exe command, which works against older systems.
Notes: Export is not possible with this switch. Recurse is implied with this switch.

maml:alert.maml:para: Properties returned : When they will show up ComputerName : All queries Name : All queries Path : COM object queries, added synthetically if we fail back from COM to SchTasks Enabled : COM object queries Action : All queries. Schtasks.exe queries include both Action and Arguments in this property Arguments : COM object queries UserId : COM object queries LastRunTime : All queries NextRunTime : All queries Status : All queries Author : All queries RunLevel : COM object queries Description : COM object queries NumberOfMissedRuns : COM object queries

Thanks to help from Brian Wilhite, Jaap Brasser, and Jan Egil's functions: http://gallery.technet.microsoft.com/scriptcenter/Get-SchedTasks-Determine-5e04513f http://gallery.technet.microsoft.com/scriptcenter/Get-Scheduled-tasks-from-3a377294 http://blog.crayon.no/blogs/janegil/archive/2012/05/28/working_2D00_with_2D00_scheduled_2D00_tasks_2D00_from_2D00_windows_2D00_powershell.aspx

command:example.dev:code: #Get scheduled tasks from the root folder of server1 and c-is-ts-91

command:example.dev:code: #Get scheduled tasks from all folders on server1, not in a Microsoft folder

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXEMPLO 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: #Get scheduled tasks from all folders on server1, not in a Microsoft folder, and export in XML format (can be used to import scheduled tasks)

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves all user sessions from local or remote computers(s)
Retrieves all user sessions from local or remote computer(s).

Note: Requires query.exe in order to run Note: This works against Windows Vista and later systems provided the following registry value is in place HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server\AllowRemoteRPC = 1 Note: If query.exe takes longer than 15 seconds to return, an error is thrown and the next computername is processed. Suppress this with -erroraction silentlycontinue Note: If $sessions is empty, we return a warning saying no users. Suppress this with -warningaction silentlycontinue
Name of computer(s) to run session query against
Parse idle time into a timespan object
Seconds to wait before ending query.exe process. Helpful in situations where query.exe hangs due to the state of the remote system.
Name of computer(s) to run session query against
Parse idle time into a timespan object
Seconds to wait before ending query.exe process. Helpful in situations where query.exe hangs due to the state of the remote system.

maml:alert.maml:para: Thanks to Boe Prox for the ideas - http://learn-powershell.net/2010/11/01/quick-hit-find-currently-logged-on-users/

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXEMPLO 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-usersession -computername "server1"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Query all current user sessions on 'server1'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXEMPLO 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-UserSession -computername $servers -parseIdleTime | ?{$_.idletime -gt [timespan]"1:00"} | ft -AutoSize

dev:remarks.maml:para: Query all servers in the array $servers, parse idle time, check for idle time greater than 1 hour.

maml:description.maml:para: This script is a script designed to remove all barriers to entry when publishing modules to the PowerShell Gallery. Before running, ensure the NuGetApiKey parameter has a default parameter value.

This script has two different purposes; to ensure your module meets all official Gallery requirements and to assist in creating your own "requirements". As-is, the script ensure your module is Gallery-ready by checking for all official requirements but also performs a couple extra tests. It's purpose is to provide a foundation to add upon to for your own "requirements" for the Gallery.

Each run will ensure a module manifest is in the same folder as the ModuleFilePath and will ensure that manifest has all of the required keys. Also, it will run Test-ModuleManifest to ensure the result passes there as well.
A mandatory string parameter representing the file path to a PSM1 file. The folder path also represents the folder that will be searched for a matching module manifest as well.

A optional PowerShell parameter yet required Gallery attribute representing the NuGet API key provided when signing up for an account with the PowerShell Gallery. This can be found by going to the URL https://www.powershellgallery.com/users/account/LogOn?returnUrl=%2F. It is recommended that your key be placed as the default parameter value to remove the need of providing it each time.

A switch parameter to enable if you'd like to run any optional tests. Currently, the only optional tests is a Pester tests file. If a file matching $ModuleName.Tests.ps1 is not in the same folder as the PSM1, it will notice this and prompt to create a simple template.
To add more tests, just add a hashtable to the $moduleTests array by copying an existing one ensuring that the Mandatory key value is as expected.
An optional switch parameter to use if you'd like to automatically published the tested module to the PowerShell Gallery. If this isn't used, you will be prompted to publish.
A mandatory string parameter representing the file path to a PSM1 file. The folder path also represents the folder that will be searched for a matching module manifest as well.

A switch parameter to enable if you'd like to run any optional tests. Currently, the only optional tests is a Pester tests file. If a file matching $ModuleName.Tests.ps1 is not in the same folder as the PSM1, it will notice this and prompt to create a simple template.
To add more tests, just add a hashtable to the $moduleTests array by copying an existing one ensuring that the Mandatory key value is as expected.

A optional PowerShell parameter yet required Gallery attribute representing the NuGet API key provided when signing up for an account with the PowerShell Gallery. This can be found by going to the URL https://www.powershellgallery.com/users/account/LogOn?returnUrl=%2F. It is recommended that your key be placed as the default parameter value to remove the need of providing it each time.
An optional switch parameter to use if you'd like to automatically published the tested module to the PowerShell Gallery. If this isn't used, you will be prompted to publish.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXEMPLO 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Publish-PowerShellGalleryModule -ModuleFilePath C:\Foo\Foo.psm1 -NuGetApiKey XXXXXXXXX

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will check the Foo module for all pre-defined requirements and fix as necessary.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXEMPLO 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Publish-PowerShellGalleryModule -ModuleFilePath C:\Modules\Foo.psm1 -RunOptionalTests

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example assumes that you've included a default value for the NuGetApiKey.

maml:description.maml:para: Displays a visual representation of a calendar.
Displays a visual representation of a calendar. This function supports multiple months and lets you highlight specific date ranges or days.
The day of the month on which the week begins.
Specific days (numbered) to highlight. Used for date ranges like (25..31). Date ranges are specified by the Windows PowerShell range syntax. These dates are enclosed in square brackets.
Specific days (named) to highlight. These dates are surrounded by asterisks.
The day of the month on which the week begins.
Specific days (numbered) to highlight. Used for date ranges like (25..31). Date ranges are specified by the Windows PowerShell range syntax. These dates are enclosed in square brackets.
Specific days (named) to highlight. These dates are surrounded by asterisks.

maml:description.maml:para: A script to wait for an action to finish.
This script executes a scriptblock represented by the Condition parameter continually while the result returns anything other than $false or $null.
A mandatory scriptblock parameter representing the code to execute to check the action condition. This code will be continually executed until it returns $false or $null.
A mandatory integer represneting the time (in seconds) to wait for the condition to complete.
An optional collection of one or more objects to pass to the scriptblock at run time. To use this parameter, be sure you have a param() block in the Condition scriptblock to accept these parameters.
An optional integer representing the time (in seconds) between the code execution in Condition.
A mandatory scriptblock parameter representing the code to execute to check the action condition. This code will be continually executed until it returns $false or $null.
A mandatory integer represneting the time (in seconds) to wait for the condition to complete.
An optional collection of one or more objects to pass to the scriptblock at run time. To use this parameter, be sure you have a param() block in the Condition scriptblock to accept these parameters.
An optional integer representing the time (in seconds) between the code execution in Condition.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXEMPLO 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Wait-Action -Condition { (Get-Job).State | where { $_ -ne 'Running' } -Timeout 10

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will wait for all background jobs to complete for up to 10 seconds.

maml:description.maml:para: Writes out calendar elements, either a single month or an entire year depending on the inputs.
If specified, will limit output to a single month with this numeral value.
If specified, will output an entire year.
If specified, holidays for the year and month are shown.
If specified with the ShowHolidays flag, observed holidays will be shown instead of the actual dates.
If specified, will limit output to a single month with this numeral value.
If specified, will output an entire year.
If specified, holidays for the year and month are shown.
If specified with the ShowHolidays flag, observed holidays will be shown instead of the actual dates.

maml:alert.maml:para: https://github.com/krispharper/Powershell-Scripts/blob/master/Write-Calendar.ps1 This script has some functionality which many would consider weird or inconsistent. Specifically, if a month is specifed and a year is not, then the output is typically the calendar for the input month and the current year. However, if the specified month is greater than 12, then it's treated as a year and the whole year is outputted.

The reason for this is to emulate the *NIX cal function, which behaves similarly. That is, cal outputs the current month, cal 2012 outpus the calendar for 2012 and cal 05 2012 outputs the calendar for May 2012.
That is pretty much how Write-Calendar works with the exception that Write-Calendar 05 will write out the calendar for May of the current year whereas cal will output the calendar for the year 5.
Since the point of this script is to emulate cal's functionality I will probably not change it to make it more consistent.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXEMPLO 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Write-Calendar

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXEMPLO 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Write-Calendar 2013

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXEMPLO 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Write-Calendar 04 2011

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXEMPLO 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Write-Calendar 7

dev:remarks.maml:para: Outputs the calendar for September of this year.
